Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by:  Archbishop Angelo Rosario, Church of God's Children, 127 Dreiser Loop, Bronx, New York.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Seabrook.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by Council Member Rev. Larry Seabrook.

Council Member Seabrook moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.MatterName: Roberta Washington, Landmarks Preservation Commission

Items.Title: Communication from the Mayor  -  “AN ACT to amend the tax law, in relation to exempting clothing and footwear sales and uses from local sales and compensating use taxes imposed in or by any city having a population of one million or more.” A.8176 / S.5864

Items.Title: Communications from City, County & Borough Offices

Items.MatterName: Recommendation of the discount rate to be allowed for early payment of real estate taxes for FY'08.

Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Communication from the Kings County Democratic County Committee - Submitting for the Advice & Consent of the Council, the name of Julie Dent, for appointment as the Kings County Democratic Commissioner of Elections for the remainder of the current term, pursuant to Section 3-204 (2) and (5) of the Election Law.
Items.ActionText: This Communication was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections
Items.MatterName: Julie Dent, for appointment as the Kings County Democratic Commissioner of Elections for the remainder of the current term.

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By Council Member Garodnick
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(c) of the Council and Section 197-d(b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Procedure Applications no. C 070125 ZSM, a special permit to allow Use Group 6 uses at 45 East 78th Street (Block 1393, Lot 25), shall be subject to Council review.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: ULURP, 45 E. 78th Street, Manhattan (C070125ZSM)

Items.Title:
By Council Member James:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and Section 197-d (b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Procedure Application Number C 070286 PPK, shall be subject to Council review.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: ULURP, City Planning Commission (C070286PPK)

Items.Title: Communication from the Speaker
Discussion of General Orders
Reports of Special Committees
Reports of Standing Committees
Report of the Committee on Education
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the protection of public employee whistleblowers.
Items.MinutesNote: Notwithstanding the objection of the Mayor, Int No. 83-A was adopted by the Council and was thereby enacted into law.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Overridden by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Protecting department of education employees from certain adverse personnel action.

Items.Title: Communication from the Mayor - Mayors veto and disapproval message of Introductory Number 83-A, in relation to the protection of public employee whistleblowers.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Mayor's Message be Filed by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Mayor's Veto - Int. No. 83-A, Protecting department of education employees from certain adverse personnel action.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Finance
Resolution to establish that the discount percentage for early payment of real estate taxes be set at 1.5% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Recommendation of the discount rate to be allowed for prepayment of real estate taxes for FY'08.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be 9% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of not more than $80,000, or not more than $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be 18% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of over $80,000, or over $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate to be charged for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of water rents and sewer rents be 18% per annum for real property where the assessed value is over $80,000, or over $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments; and 9% per annum for real property where the assessed value is not more than $80,000, or not more $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the United States Congress to end federal raids to deport undocumented immigrants and institute comprehensive immigration reform that protects the fundamental civil liberties of immigrants and integrates immigrants fully into American society.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Immigration
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 8 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Avella, Felder, Gallagher, Gentile, Ignizio, McMahon, Vallone, Jr., and Oddo.

The following 2 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item: 
Council Members Fidler and Vacca.

The following 2 Council Members were present but not voting (non-voting):
Council Members Garodnick and Lappin.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Congress to end federal raids to deport undocumented immigrants and institute comprehensive immigration reform that protects the fundamental civil liberties of immigrants and integrates immigrants fully into American society.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Smith, S.1861, and Assembly Member Cook, A.3548, “AN ACT authorizing the city of New York to reconvey its interest in certain real property acquired by in rem tax foreclosure in the borough of Queens to former owner Morris Brown Church, notwithstanding expiration of the two year period within which application may be made to the city to release its interest in property thus acquired; Block No. 12048, Lot No. 85 on tax map for the borough of Queens”.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Golden, S.5766-A, and Assembly Member Farrell, A.8161-A, “AN ACT to amend the real property tax law, in relation to a rebate of real property taxes on certain residential real property in a city having a population of one million or more”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Rebate on real property taxes.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of environmental protection to update billing information when real property is transferred.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of environmental protection to update billing information when real property is transferred.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to property of public service corporations affected by public works projects.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Property of public service corporations affected by public works projects.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the sale of toys and child care products that contain phthalates or bisphenol A.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Sale of toys, childcare and child feeding products that contain phthalates.

Items.Title: Resolution calling for the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, the Pay Equity legislative package.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Women's Issues
Items.MatterName: Pay Equity legislative package.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to pass Assembly bill A.3763 and Senate bill S.3359, which would amend the criminal procedure law to enable judges, if so requested, to instruct juries in criminal proceedings to disregard appeals made to bias and prejudice through courtroom tactics such as “panic strategies.”
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Criminal Justice Services
Items.MatterName: Amend the criminal procedure law to enable judges, if so requested, to instruct juries in criminal proceedings to disregard appeals made to bias and prejudice through courtroom tactics such as “panic strategies.”

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the defacing or damaging of American flags on private property.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Defacing or damaging of American flags on private property.

Items.Title: Resolution declaring November to be New York City History Month.
Items.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: Declaring November to be New York City History Month.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to amend the Hudson River Park Act to authorize a marine transfer station and environmental education center in the Gansevoort peninsula in lower Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MatterName: State Legislature to amend the Hudson River Park Act to authorize a marine transfer station and environmental education center in the Gansevoort peninsula in lower Manhattan.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the discount percentage for early payment of real estate taxes be set at 1.5% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Recommendation of the discount rate to be allowed for prepayment of real estate taxes for FY'08.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be 9% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of not more than $80,000, or not more than $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be 18% per annum for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of over $80,000, or over $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate to be charged for Fiscal Year 2008 for non-payment of water rents and sewer rents be 18% per annum for real property where the assessed value is over $80,000, or over $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments; and 9% per annum for real property where the assessed value is not more than $80,000, or not more $80,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Recommendations of the interest rate to be charged for FY'08 for non-payment of taxes on real estate, and for non-payment of water and sewer rents.

Items.MinutesNote: The Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

At this point, the Speaker (Council Member Quinn) asked for a Moment of Silence for the following individual:  

Army Spc. Alexander Rosa, Jr., 22, born and raised in N.Y.C. before moving with his family to Florida, who died on May 25, 2007 in Iraq of wounds suffered when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle.  He was assigned to the 293rd Military Police Company out of Fort Stewart Georgia.  Spc. Rosa was the cousin of Council Member Rosie Mendez.  He leaves behind his wife, Melissa, a two month old daughter, his mother, brother, sister and his grandparents.
